title: What Is Bacterial Pneumonia?
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: Bacterial pneumonia is an infection of your lungs caused by certain bacteria. The most common one is Streptococcus (pneumococcus), but other bacteria can cause it too. If you’re young and basically healthy, these bacteria can live in your throat without causing any trouble. But if your body’s defenses (immune system) become weak for some reason, the bacteria can go down into your lungs . When this happens, the air sacs in your lungs get infected and inflamed. They fill up with fluid, and that causes pneumonia .

People who have a weakened immune system also have an increased risk for bacterial pneumonia. These include those who recently had an organ transplant . People who are HIV positive, or who have leukemia , lymphoma , or severe kidney disease also stand a greater chance of developing the infection.

Don’t eat right or get enough vitamins and minerals

sections.heading: Symptoms
content: The symptoms can come on fast and furious, or they can creep up on you over a few days. Common symptoms are:
bullets: Coughing out greenish, yellow, or bloody mucus
Feeling like you can’t catch your breath, especially when you move around a lot
Sharp or stabby chest pain , especially when you cough or take a deep breath

sections.heading: Prevention
content: There are two kinds of shots for bacterial pneumonia:
PCV13 ( Prevnar 13) is for:
PPSV23 ( Pneumovax ) is for:
Talk to your doctor to find out if you or your child should get a shot.
Besides getting shots, you can lower your risk of getting bacterial pneumonia by doing these things:
bullets: People who have a high risk of bacterial pneumonia
Children older than 2 who have a high risk of bacterial pneumonia
People between 19 and 64 who smoke or have asthma
Wash your hands regularly, especially after you go to the bathroom and before you eat.
Eat right, with plenty of fruits and vegetables .
Stay away from sick people, if possible.

sections.heading: Diagnosis
content: Your doctor might be able to tell if you have bacterial pneumonia just by examining you and asking questions about your symptoms and general health. They’ll probably listen to your lungs with a stethoscope. That will allow them to hear sounds that show there’s fluid in your lungs. But if they are not sure, you might have to get a chest X-ray.
Some people may need extra tests. These might include:
bullets: Pulse oximetry (a small gizmo clipped to your finger that checks for enough oxygen in your blood )
Tests of the gunk you cough up (“sputum”)
CT scan to look more closely at your lungs

sections.heading: Treatment
content: Your doctor probably will prescribe antibiotics . It’s very important that you finish all of these. Otherwise the bacteria may not all be killed and you could get sick all over again. Your doctor might also suggest medication for pain and fever.
Other things you can do to help yourself get better:
bullets: Drink plenty of fluids (they’ll loosen up the gunk in your lungs so you can cough it out).
Use a humidifier or take a warm bath (more gunk-loosening).
Stay home until your fever goes down and you aren’t coughing anything out.

content: Most people who are treated for bacterial pneumonia start feeling better in a few days, but it can take a few weeks before you feel 100% better. Make sure you keep your follow-up appointments so your doctor can check your lungs.
If the pneumonia is stubborn or severe, you might have to go to the hospital. If you go to the hospital you might get:
bullets: Treatments to help loosen up the gunk
